titleStmt.title: Hengist, King of Kent by Thomas Middleton

editionStmt.p: This electronic version was produced at the Centre for Literary and Linguistic Computing at the University of Newcastle by keyboarding from a microfilm printout of an early printed version. It was originally in a format devised in the Centre, with reference panels at the beginning of each line, known as "LILAC". It was subsequently converted by an automated process to a TEI XML format. It lacks the speaker tags provided in the copytext. Contractions and variant spellings of function words have been silently regularised. The text thus lacks information about the original forms of many words and expressions.

publicationStmt.publisher: Published for the Malone Society by Oxford University Press

sourceDesc.p:
Play details
Hengist, King of Kent or The Mayor of Quinborough. Genre: Tragedy. Date first published: 1661. Date first performed: Mar 1615-Aug 1613?

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations.
Hengist, King of Kent
Vortiger Constantius, King of Britons Lord Devonshire Lord Stafford Germanus, monk Raynulph, chorus Castiza Roxena Aurelius Horsus Simon, tanner Oliver, weaver Uther Ladies Combined voice 1 Grazier 2 Grazier Fellmonger Buttonmonger Brazier 1 Gentleman 2 Gentleman Barber Tailor Glover Aminadab, clerk Footman 1 Cheater 2 Cheater Clown

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

stage.l: Enter Raynulph a Munck the prsenter

sp.l: What Raynulph Monk of Chester Can
Raise from his policronicon,
(That raises him as works do Men
To see light so long parted with again)
That best may please this round fair ring
With sparkling judgements: Circled in,
I shall produce; if all my powers
Can win the grace of too poor hours;
Well apaid I go to rest.
Ancient stories have been best,
Fashions that are now Called new
Have been worn by more than you,
Elder times have used the same
Though these new ones get the name,
so in story what is now told
That takes not part with days of old?
Then to prove times mutual glory
Join new times love, to old times story.
Will that wide throated Beast the Multitude
Never Lyn Bellowing?
Courtiers are ill advised
When they first make such Monsters:
What do they but make head against themselves by it?
How near was I to a Sceptre and a Crown,
Fair power was even upon me, my desires
Were tasting glory, till this forked rabble
With their infectious acclamations
Poisoned my fortune; they will here have none
As long as Contantins three sons Survive,
As if the vassals knew not how to obey
But in that line, like their professions
That all their life time hammer out one way
Beaten into their pates with seven years Bondage;
Well! though I rise not King I will seek the means
To grow as Close to one as policy Can
And Choke their expectations: now good Lords
In whose kind loves and wishes I am Built
As high as human dignity Can aspire,
Are yet those Trunks that have no other souls
But noise and Ignorance, something more quiet?
Nor are they like to be for aught we gather;
Their wills are up still, nothing will appease them,
Good speeches are but Cast away upon them.
Then since necessity and fate withstand me
I will strive to enter at a straighter passage;
Your sudden aides and Counsels good my Lords.
They are ours no longer than they do you service.

stage.l: Musick Enter Certaine Muncks, Germanus; Constantius being

sp.l: Boast not of high Birth or Blood,
To be great is to be good;
Holy and religious things
Those are vestures fit for Kings;
By how much Man in fame shines Clearer
He to heaven should draw the nearer,
He deserving best of praises
whom virtue raises;
It is not state, it is not Birth;
The way to heaven is grace on earth.
Sing to the Temple him so holy
Sin may Blush to think of folly.
Vessels of sanctity, be pleased awhile
To give attention to the public peace
Wherein heaven is served too; though not so purely;
Constantius eldest son of Constantine
We here seize on thee for the general good
And in thy right of Birth,
On me! for what Lords!
The Kingdoms goverment.
O powers of Blessedness
Keep me from growing downwards into earth again,
I hope I am further on my way than so;
Set forward
You must not
How?
I know your wisdom
Will light upon a way to pardon us
When you shall read in every
Britains brow
The urged necessity of the times.
What necessity
Can be in the world, but prayer and repentance,
And that Business I am about.
Hark, afar off still,
We lose and hazard much: holy Germanus
And reverend Lupus, with all expedition
Set the Crown on him.
No such mark of fortune
Comes near my head
My Lord we are forced to rule you
Dare you receive heavens light in at your eye Lids
And over violence to religion; take heed,
The very Beam let in to Comfort you
May be the fire to burn you, on these knees
Hardened with zealous prayers I entreat you,
Bring not my Cares into the world again,
Think with how much unwillingness and anguish,
A glorified soul departed from the Body,
Would to that loathsome gaol return again,
With such great pain, a well subdued affection
Re-enters worldly Business.
Good my Lord
I know you Cannot Lodge so many virtues
But patience must be one; as low as earth
We Beg the freeness of
your own Consent
Which ells must be Constrained, and time it were
Either agreed, or forced, speak good my Lord
For you bind up more sin in this delay,
Than thousand prayers Can absolve again.
Were it but my death you should not kneel so long for it.
It will be the death of millions if you rise not,
And that betimes too: lend your helps my Lords
For fear all Come too late,
This is a Cruelty
That peaceful Man did never suffer yet,
To make me die again, that was once dead
And begin all that ended long before:
Hold Lupus and Germanus you are lights
Of holiness and religion, Can you over
The thing that is not lawful, stand not I
Clear from all temporal Charge by my profession?
Not when a time so violent Calls upon you;
Who is born a Prince is born for general peace
Not his own only,
heaven will look for him
In others business, and require him there;
What is in you religious must be shown
In saving many more souls
than your own
Did not great Constantine our noble father
Deem me unfit for government and rule
And therefore pressed me into this profession:
Which I have held strict and love it above glory?
Nor is there want in me yourselves Can witness
Heaven has provided largely for your peace
And blessed you with the lives of my two Brothers:
Fix your obedience there, leave me a servant.
You may even at this Instant
O this Cruelty
Long live Constantius son of Constantine King of the
Britains.
They have Changed their tune already
I feel want
And extreme poverty of Joy within me,
The peace I had is parted amongst rude men,
To keep them quiet I have lost it all:
What Can the Kingdom gain by my undoing?
That riches is not blessed though it be mighty
That is purchased with the spoil of any man,
Nor Can the peace so filched,
ever thrive with them:
And if it be worthily held sacrilege,
To rob a Temple, it is no less offence
To ravish meditations from a soul
The Consecrated alter in a Man,
And all their hopes will be beguiled in me;
I know no more the way to temporal rule
Than he that is born and has his years Come to him
In a rough desert; well may the weight kill me
And that is the fairest good I look for from it.
Not so great King: here stoops a faithful servant
Would sooner perish under it with Cheerfulness
Than your meek soul should feel the least oppression
Of ruder Cares: such Common Course employments
Cast upon me your subject, upon vortiger,
I see you are not made for noise and pains
Clamours of suitors, injuries and redresses,
Millions of rising actions with the sun,
Like laws still ending and
yet never Done,
Of power, to turn a great man to the state
Of his insensible monument, with overwatching;
To be oppressed, is not required of you my Lord
But only to be King,
the Broken sleeps
Let me take from you sir, the toils and troubles,
All that is Burdensome in authority
Please you to lay it on me, and what is glorious
Receive it to your own Brightness
Worthy vortiger
If it were not sin to grieve another's patience
With what we Cannot tolerate ourselves
How happy were I in thee, and thy Charity;
There is nothing makes man feele his miseries,
But knowledge only, reason that is placed
For man's director, is his Chief afflicter,
For though I Cannot bear the weight myself
I Cannot have that Bareness of remorse
To see another groan under my Burthen.
I am quite blown up, a Conscionable way,
There is even a trick
of murdering in some pity.
The death of all my hopes I see already,
They are was no other likelihood: for religion
Was never friend of mine yet,
Holy partners
In strictest abstinence, fastings and vigils,
Cruel necessity has forced me from you,
We part I fear forever, But in mind
I will be always here, here let me staye.
My Lord you know the times
Farewell Blessed souls, I fear I much offend
He that draws tears from you, takes your best friend
Can this great motion of Ambition stand
Like wheels false wrought by an unskilful hand,
Then time stand thou too, let no hopes arrive
At their sweet wishfulness till mine set forward,
Would I Could stay this existence; as I Can
Thy glassy Counterfeit in hours of sand;
I would keep thee turned down till my wishes rose,
Then we would both rise together;
What serially inclinations are in nature:
How much is he disquieted, and wears royalty
Disdainfully upon him like a Curse,
Calls a fair Crown the weight of his afflictions
When here is a soul would sing under that Burthen.
Yet well recovered: I will seek all ways
To vex authority from him, I will weary him
As low as the Condition of a hound
Before I give him over, and in all
Study what most may discontent his Blood
Making my mask my zeal, to the public good.
Not possible a richer policy
Can have Conception in the thought of Man
An honourable life enclose your Lordship
Now what are you
Graziers if it like your Lordship:
so it should seem by your enclosures
What is your affairs with me
We are your Petitioners my Lord
What: depart,
Petitioners to me, you have well deserved
My grace and friendship: have you not a Ruler
After your own election,
high to Court
Get near and Close, be loud and bold enough
You Cannot Choose but speed
And that will do it,
We have throats wide enough, we will put them to it

stage.l: ffortune is discouered upon an alter, in
her hand a golden round full of Lotts: Enter Hengist
and Hersus with others, they Draw Lotts and hang them up
with Ioy, so all depart saueing
Hengist and Hersus who kneele and imbrace
each other as parteners in one fortune, to them
Enter Roxena seemeing to take her leaue of
Hengist her father, But especeally priuately and
warily of Hersus her louer; she departs weepeing:
and Hengist and Hersus go to the doore and Bring
in their souldiers with Drum and Collors and so

sp.l: When Germany was overgrown
With sons of peace too thickly sown
Several guides were Chosen then
By destined lots to lead out Men
And they whom fortune here withstands
Must prove their fates in other Lands:
On these two Captains fell that Lot
But that which must not be forgot
Was Roxenas Cunning grief
Who from the father like a thief
Hid her best and truest tears
In many a stolne and wary kiss
Unseen of father: that maids will do this
Yet highly scorn to be Called strumpets too --
But what they lack of it I will be judged by you
This way his Majesty Comes
Thank your good Lordship
When you hear yond door open
Very good my Lord
Be ready with your serially suites, put forward
That is a thing every Man does naturally sir
That is a suitor if he mean to speed
It is well you are so deep Learned, take no denials,
No my good Lord
Not any if you love
The prosperity of your suites; you mar all utterly,
And overthrow your fruitful hopes forever,
If either fifth or sixth nay tenth repulse
Fasten upon your Bashfulness
Say you so my Lord,
We Can be troublesome if we list
I know it,
I felt it but too late in the general some
Of your rank Brotherhood, which now I will thank you for;
While this vexation is in play, I will study
To raise a second, then a third to that
One still to back another: I will make quietness
As dear and precious to him as nights rest
To a man in suites in law, he shall be glad
To yield up power; if not, it shall be had
Hark, I profess my heart was Coming upward,
I thought the door had opened
Marry would it had sir
I have such a treacherous heart of mine own, it will
throb at the very fall of a farthingale
Not if it fall on the rushes
Yes truly if there be no light in the room, I shall
throb presently; the first time it took me my wife
was in the Company, I remember the room was not
half so light as this, but I will be sworn I was a whole
hour afinding of her
By our Lady you had a long time of throbbing of it then
Still I felt men, But I Could find no women, I
thought they had been all sunk, I have made a vow
for it I will never have a
meeting by Candlelight again
Yes sir in Lanterns
Yes sir in Lanterns, But I will
never trust a naked
Candle again, take it on my word
Hark there, stand Close, it opens now indeed
O Majesty what art thou, I would give any man half
my suite to deliver my petition now, it is in the behalf
Of Button makers and so it seems by my flesh.
Pray do not follow me, unless you do it
To wonder at my garments: there is no Cause
I give you why you should: it is shame enough
Methinks for me to look upon myself;
It grieves me that more should: the other weeds
Became me better; but the Lords are pleased
To force me to wear these, I would not else:
I pray be satisfied, I Called you not.
Wonder of madness! can you stand so Idle
And know that you must die
We are all Commanded sir,
Besides it is our duty to your grace
To give attendance
What a wild thing is this:
We marvel though you tremble at Deaths name
When you will not see the Cause why you are Cowards?
All our attendances are far too little
On our own selves,
yet you will give me attendance;
Who looks to you the whilst, and so you vanish
Strangely and fearfully; for Charity's sake
Make not my presence guilty of your sloth;
Withdraw young men and find you honest business
What hopes have we to rise by following him?
I will give him over shortly.
He is too nice
Too holy for young gentlemen to follow
That have good faces and sweet running fortunes
Eight hours a day in serious Contemplation
Is But a bare allowance, no higher food
To the soul, than Bread and water to the Body,
And that is but needful then; more would do better
Let us all kneel together, it will move pity
I have been at begging a hundredth suites
How happy am I in the sight of you:
Here are religious souls that lose no time;
With what Devotion do they kneel to heaven
And seem to Check me that am so remiss.
I Bring my Zeal amongst you, holy men,
If I see any kneel, and I sit out,
That hour is not well served methinks: strict souls
You have been of some order in your times
Graziers and Braziers some and this a felmonger
Here is my Petition
Mine if it like your grace
Look upon mine I am the longest suitor
I was undone seven years ago my Lord
I have mocked my good hopes: call you these petitions
Why there is no form of prayer amongst them all
Yes in the Bottom there is some half a Line
Prays for your Majesty if you look on mine
Make your request to heaven not to me
Alas mine is a supplication for brass buttons sir.
There is a great enormity in wool, I beseech your grace
Consider it
Pastures rise to twopence an acre my Lord, what will this
world Come to.
I do beseech your grace
Good your grace
O this is one of my afflictions
That with the Crown enclosed me, I must bear it
Your graces answer to my supplication
to mine my Lord
No violent storm lasts ever,
That is all the Comfort of it
Your highness answer
We are almost half undone, the Country almost Beggared
See see he points to heaven, as who should say
There is enough there, But it is a great way thither,
There is no good to be done here I see that, we may all spend
our mouths like a Company of hounds in the Chase
of a royal dear, and go home and fall to Cold mutton
bones when we have done
My wife will hang me that is my destiny,
Thanks heaven it is over, we should
never know rightly
The sweetness of a Calm but for a tempest;
Here is a wished hour for Contemplation now;
All still and silent, this is a true Kingdom,
My lord
Again
Alas this is but early
And gentle to the troops of businesses
That flock about authority, my Lord
You must forthwith settle your mind to marry
Suddenly, there is no pause given;
The peoples wills are violent
And Covetous of succession from your Loins
From me there Can Come none; a professed abstinence
Hath set a virgin seal upon my Blood
And altered all the Course; the heat I have
Is all enclosed within a zeal to virtue,
And that is not fit for earthly propagation:
Alas I shall but forfeit all their hopes,
I am a man made without desires tell them
This gives no satisfaction to their wills my Lord;
I proud them with such words But all were fruitless,
Their sturdy voices Blew them into Clouds;
A Virgin of the highest Subjects Blood
They have picked out for your embrace, and send her
Blessed with their general wishes into fruitfulness;
See where she Comes my Lord
I never felt
Unhappy hand of misery till this touch:
A patience I could find for all but this
My Lord your vowed Love ventures me but dangerously
It is but to strengthen a vexation politicly
That is an uncharitable practise, trust me sir
No more of that
But say he should effect me sir
How should I scape him then, I have but one faith my Lord
And that you have already, our late Contract is
A Divine witness to it
Leave it to me still
I am not without shifting rooms and helps
For all my projects I commit with you!
It is an ungodly way to Come to honour,
I do not like it, I love Lord Vortiger
But not these practises, they are too uncharitable
Are you a virgin
Never yet my Lord,
Known to the will of Man
O blessed Creature
And does too much felicity make you surfeit,
Are you in soul assured there is a state
Prepared for you, for you, a glorious one
In midst of heaven now in the state you stand in
And had you rather after much known misery
Cares and hard labours mingled with a Curse,
Throng but to the door and hardly get a place there?
Think, has the world a folly like this madness;
Keep still that holy and immaculate fire
You Chaste Lamp of eternity, it is a treasure
Too precious for deaths moment to partake,
This twinkling of short life; Disdain as much
To let mortality know you, as stars
To kiss the pavements, you have a substance
As excellent as theirs, holding your pureness;
They look upon Corruption as you do
But are stars still; be you a virgin too
I will never marry,
what though my troth be engaged
To vortiger; forsaking all the world
I save it well, and do my faith no wrong:
You have mightily prevailed, great virtuous Lord
I am bound eternally to praise your goodness
I Carry thoughts away as pure from man
As ever made a virgins name immortal
I will do that for joy
I never did
Nor ever will again
My Lord he is taken
I am sorry for it, I like not that so well,
They are somewhat too familiar for their time methinks;
This way of kissing is no Course to vex him:
Why I that have a weaker faith and patience
Could endure more than that Coming from woman;
Dispatch and Bring his answer speedily
My Lord, my gracious Lord
Beshrew thy heart
They all attend your grace
I would not have them,
It would please me better if they would all depart,
And leave the Court to me, or put me out
And take it to themselves
The noon is past my Lord,
Meat is upon the Table
Meat, away, get from me,
Thy memory is diseased; what saints Eves this
Saint Agatha I take it
O is it so
I am not worthy to be served before her,
And so return I pray
He will starve the guard, and this be suffered; if we set Court
Bellies by a Monastery Clock, he that breaks a fellows pate
now, will scarce be able to Crack a louse within this twelve-month
Sure it is forgetfulness and not man's will,
That leads him forth into Licentious ways,
He Cannot Certainly Commit such errors,
And think upon them truly, as they are acting:
Why is abstinence ordained but for such seasons
My Lord you have pleased to put us to much pains
But we Confess it is portion of our Duties;
Will your grace please to walk, dinner stays for you.
I have answered that already
But my Lord
We must not so yield to you, pardon me,
It is for the general good, you must be ruled sir:
Your health and life is dearer to us now,
Think where you are, at Court, this is no monastery
But sir my Conscience keeps still where it was
I may not eat this day
We have sworn you shall
And plentifully too, we must preserve you Sir:
Though you will be wilful; it is no slight Condition
To be a King
Would I were less than Man
What, will you make the people rise my Lord,
In great despair of your Continuance
If you neglect the means that must sustain you
I never eat on Eves
But now you must
It Concerns others healths that you take food
You have Changed your life, you may well Change your mood
This is beyond all Cruelty
It is our Care my Lord
My Lord I am resolved, tempt me no further
It is all to fruitless purpose
Are you well
Never so perfect
in the truth of health
As at this Instant
Then I doubt mine own
Or that I am not waking,
Would you were then,
You would praise my resolution.
This is wondrous
Are you not mine by Contract.
It is most true my Lord
And I am better blessed in it, than I looked for,
In that I am confined in faith so strictly
I am bound my Lord to marry none but you
You will grant me that, and you
I will never marry
It draws into me violence and hazard
I saw you kiss the King
I grant you so sir
Where Could I take my leave of the world better
I wronged not you; in that you will acknowledge
A King is the best part of it
O my passion
I see you somewhat yielding to infirmity Sir
I take my leave
Why it is not possible
The fault is in your faith, time I was gone
To give it Better strengthening
Hark you Lady
Send your intent to the next monastery,
There you shall find my answer ever after,
And so with my Last duty to your Lordship
For whose perfections I will pray as heartily
As for mine own
How am I served in this:
I offer a vexation to the King,
He sends it home into my blood with vantage;
I will putt off time no Longer; I have wrought him
Into most men's neglect; Calling his zeal
A deep pride, hallowed over, love of ease
More than devotion, or the public benefit
Which Catches many men's beliefs; I am stronger too
In peoples wishes, their affections point to me;
I lose much time and glory; that redeemed,
She that now flies, returns with Joy and wonder
Greatness and Woman's wish
never keep asunder

stage.l: Hoboys Dumb show. Enter 2 Villaines, to them Vortiger
seemeing to solissitt them, giues them gold, then sweares
them -- Exit Vortiger Enter to them Constantius in
priuate meditation, they rudely Come to him, strike
down his Booke and Draw their swordes upon him,
he fairely spreddes his armes, and yeilds to their furys
at which they seeme to be ouer Come with pittye, But lookeing
on the gold kill him as he turns his Back, and hurry away
his bodye Enter Vortiger Deuon: Stafford in
priuate Conference: to them Enter the murderers
prsenting the head to Vortiger, he seems to express much
sorrow, and before the astonished Lordes, makes
officers lay hold on them; who offering to Come towardes
Vortiger are Commanded to be hurryed
away as to execution: then the Lordes, all seemeing
respect, Crowne Vortiger, then bring in Castiza,
who seems to be brought in vnwillingly by Deuon:
and Stafford who Crowne her and then give her
to Vortiger, she going forth with him, with a kind of
Constraind Consent; then enter Aurelius and Vther
the two Brothers who much astonished seeme to fly for

sp.l: When nothing Could prevail to tire
The good Kings patience, Death had hire
In wicked strengths to take his life,
In whom a while there fell a strife
Of Pity and fury, but the gold
Made pity faint, and fury bold;
Then to Vortiger they Bring
The head of that religious King
Who faining grief to Clear his guilt
Makes the slaughterers Blood be spilt:
Then Crown they him, and force the maid
That vowed a virgin life to wed,
Such a strength great power extends
It Conquers fathers, kin, and friends;
And since fate is pleased to Change her Life
She proves as holy in a wife:
More to tell were to betraye
What deeds in their
own tongues must say,
Only this the good King dead
The Brothers poor in safety fled.
My Lord
I fear thy news will fetch a Curse
It Comes with such a violence
The people are up in arms against you
O this dream of glory, I Could wish
A sting into thee; there is no such felt in Hell,
The fellow but to mine I feel now:
Sweet power before I Can have power to taste thee
Must I forever Lose thee: what is the imposthume
That swells them now,
The murder of Constantius
Ulcers of realms, they hated him alive,
Grew weary of the minute of his reign
Compared with some kings time, and poisoned him
Often before he died, in their black wishes;
Called him an evil of their own electing,
And is their ignorant zeal so fiery now,
When all their thanks are Cold, the mutable hearts
That move in their false breasts: provide me safety;
Hark I hear ruin threaten me, with a voice
That imitates thunder.
Where is the King
Who takes him
Send peace to all your royal thoughts my Lord
A fleet of valiant saxons newly Landed
Offer the truth of all their service to you

stage.l: Enter Hengist Hersus Drum and soldiers

sp.l: Saxons! my wishes; let them have free Entrance
And plenteous welcomes from all hearts that love us,
They never Could Come happier
Health power and victory to Vortiger
They are Can be no more wished to a Kings pleasures
If all the Languages earth speaks were ransacked
Your names I know not, But so much good fortune
And warranted worth lightens your fair aspects!
I Cannot But in arms of love enfold you;
The Mistress of or Births, hope-fruitful-germany
Calls me Hengistus and this Captain Horsus,
A man low built, But sir in acts of valour
Flame is not swifter: we are all my Lord
The sons of fortune, she has sent us forth
To thrive, by the red sweat of
our own merits:
And since after the rage of many a tempest
Our fate has Cast us upon Britains Bounds
We offer you the first fruits of our wounds
Which we shall dearly prize, the meanest blood spent
Shall at wealths fountain make his
own Content.
You double vigour in us then my Lord
Pay is the soul of them that thrive by the sword

stage.l: Allarums and skirmish Enter Vortiger and Gentleman

sp.l: My Lord these saxons bring a fortune with them
Stains any Romaine success.
On, speak forward,
I will not take a moment from thy tidings
The main supporters of this insurrection
They have taken prisoners, and the rest so tame
They stoop to the least grace that flows from mercy
Never Came power guided with
better stars
Than these men's fortitudes, yet they are misbelievers
It is to my reason wondrous

stage.l: Enter Heng: Horsus with Drums and Colours soldiers leading prisoners

sp.l: You have given me such a first taste of your worth
It will never from my love,
sure when life is gone
The memory will follow my soul still
Participating immortality with it:
And here is the misery of earths limited glory
There is not a way revealed to give you honour
Above the sum which your
own praises give you.
Indeed my lord we hold when all is summed up
That Can be made for worth to be expressed
The fame that a Man wins himself is best;
That he may Call his own,
honours put to him
Make him no more a man than his Clothes do
And as soon taken off, for as in warmth
The heat Comes from the body, not the weeds,
So man's true fame, must strike from
his own deeds;
And since by this event which fortune speaks us
This Land appears the fair predestined soil
Ordained for our good hap: We Crave my Lord
A little earth to thrive on: what you please
Where we will but keep a Nursery of good spirits
To fight for you and yours.
Sir for our treasure
It is open to your merits, as our love,
But for you are strangers in religion Chiefly,
Which is the greatest alienation Can be,
And breeds most factions in the bloods of men
I must not grant you that.
'sprecious my lord
I see a pattern, Be it but so little
As yond poor hide will Compass
How, the hide
Rather than nothing sir
Since you are so reasonable
Take so much in the best part of our Kinsmen
We thank your grace, rivers from bubbling springs
Have rise at first, and great from abject things:
Stay yonder fellow, he Came Luckily
And he shall fare well for it,
whatever he be;
We will thank our fortune in rewarding him
Stay fellow
How, fellow, it is more than you know whether I be your fellow
or no for I am sure you see me not
Come what is the price of your Hide
O unreasonable villain, he would buy the house
over a
man's head, I will be sure now to make my bargain
wisely, they may buy me out of my skin else;
whose hide would you have, mine or the Beasts, there is
little difference in their Complexions, I think mine
be the better of the twain, you shall see for your love
and buy for your money, a pestilence on you all, how
have you gulled me; you buy an oxide, you buy a
good Calf's gather: they are all hungry soldiers
and I took them for shoemakers
Hold fellow; prithee hold: right a fool worldling
That kicks at all good fortune, whose man art thou
I am a servant, yet I am a Masterless man sir.
How; prithee how is that now
Very nimbly sir: my Masters dead and I serve my Mistress.
I am a Masterless man sir, she is now a widow, and I
am the foreman of her tan pit
Hold you and thank your fortune not your wit
Faith and I thank your Bounty and not your wisdom, you are
not troubled greatly with wit neither it seems; now
by this light a nest of yellow whammers, what will
become of me; if I Can keep all these without hanging
of myself, I am happier than a hundred of my neighbours:
you shall have my skin into the bargain too,
willingly sir, then if I chance to die like a dog, the labour
will be saved of fleeing. I will undertake sir. you shall
have all the skins of our parish at this rate, man and
woman's;
Sirrah give ear to me now; take your hide
And Cut it all into the slenderest thongs
That Can bear strength to hold.
That were a Jest indeed, go and spoil all the Leather;
sin and pity, why it would shoe half your army
Do it I bid you
What, Cut it all in thongs: hunch: this is like the vanity of
your Roman gallants that Cannot wear good suites
but they must have them Cut and slashed into Jiggets
that the very Crimson Taffety sits blushing at their
follies: I would I might persuade you sir from the
humour of Cutting, it is but a kind of swaggering Condition
and nothing profitable, what if it were but well
pinked, it would last Longer for a summer suit.
What a gross lump of ignorance have I lighted on
I must be forced to beat my drift into him:
Look you, to make you wiser than your parents,
I have so much ground given me, as this hide will Compass
Which as it is, is nothing
Nothing quotha,
Why it will not keep a hog
Now with the vantage
Cut into several parcels it will stretch far
And make a liberal circuit
A shame on your Crafty Hide, is this your Cunning; I have
learned more knavery now than ever I shall
shake off while I live: I will go purchase lands by Cows
tails, and undo the parish: three good Bulls pizzles would set
up a Man forever, this is like a pin a day doubled to set up
a haberdasher of small wares
Thus men as mean to thrive, as we must learn Captain
Set in a foot at first
A foot do you Call it,
The Devil is in that foot, that takes up all
This Leather.
Dispatch, away, and Cut it Carefully
With all the advantage sirrah
You Could never have lighted
upon such a fellow Captain
to serve your turn; I have such a trick of stretching too, I
learnt it of a tanners Man that was hanged last sessions,
that I will warrant you I will get you in a mile and a
half more than you are aware of
Pray serve me so as oft as you will sir.
I am Casting about for nine Acres to make you a garden
plot, out of one of the Buttocks
It will be a good soil for nosegays
It will be a good soil for Cabbages, to stuff out the guts
of your fellows there
You sirs go see it Carefully performed
It is the first foundations of our fortunes
On Britains earth, and ought to be embraced
With a respect, near linked to adoration:
Methinks it sounds to me a fair assurance
Of large honours and hopes; does it not Captain?
How many have begun with less at first
That have departed Emperors from their Bodies
And left their Carcasses as much in monument
As would erect a College,
There is the fruits
Of their religious shows too, to lie rotting
Under a Million spent in gold and marble
When thousands left behind dies without shelter
Having nor house nor food;
A precious Charity
But where shall we make Choice of our ground Captain
About the fruitful Banks of ubrious Kent
A fat and Olive soil, there we Came in
O Captain he has given I know not what
Long may he give so
I tell thee sirrah he that begged a field
Of fourscore Acres for a garden plot
It was pretty well but he Came short of this
Send over for more saxons
With all speed Captain
Especially for Roxena
Who my daughter
That star of Germany, forget not her sir.
She is a fair fortunate maid, I shall betray myself,
Fair is she and most fortunate may she be
But in maid lost forever, my desire
Has been the Close Confusion of that name
A treasure it is, able to make more thieves
Than Cabinets set open to entice,
Which learns one theft,
that never knew the vice
Some I will dispatch with speed
Do you forget not
Marry pray help my memory if I should.
Roxena you remember
What more dear sir
I see you need not help, your memory is Clear sir
Those sounds leapt from our Army
They were too Cheerful
To voice a bad event,
Now sir your news
Roxena the fair
True she shall be sent for.
She is here
What sayst
She is Come sir
A new youth
Begins me over again
Followed you Close sir.
With such a zeal as Daughter never equalled
Exposed herself to all the merciless dangers
Set in mankind or fortune, not regarding
Aught but your sight
Her love is Infinite to me
Most Charitably censured; it is her Cunning,
The love of her own lust,
which makes a woman
Gallop down hill as fearless as a drunkard,
There is no true Lodestone in the world but that;
It draws them through all storms, by sea or shame;
Life's loss is thought too small to pay that game
What follows more of her will take you strongly
How
Nay it is worth your wonder
I thirst for it
Her heart Joy ravished at your late success
Being the early morning of your fortunes
So prosperously now opening at her Coming
She takes a Cup of gold and midst the army
Teaching her knee a Current Cheerfulness
Which well became her, drank a liberal health
To the Kings joys and yours, the King in presence
Who with her sight but her behaviour Chiefly
Or Chief I know not which, but one, or both,
But he is so far above my expression Caught,
It were Art enough for one man's time and portion
To speak him and miss nothing
This is astonishing
O this ends bitter now, our Close hid flame
Will break out of my heart, I Cannot keep it
Gave you attention to this Captain, how now man
A kind of grief about these times of the moon still,
I feel a pain like a Convulsion
A Cramp at heart, I know not what name fits it
Nor never seek one for it, let it go
without a name, would all griefs were served so
Our using of them mannerly makes them grow
A love knot already, arm in arm
What is he lays Claim here
In right of fatherhood
I Challenge an obedient part my Lord
Take it and send back the rest
What means your grace
You will keep no more than what belongs to you, will you,
That is all my Lord, it all belongs to me yet,
I keep a husbands Interest till he Come,
Yet out of duty and respect of majesty
I send her back your servant
my Mistress sir or nothing
Come again
I never thought
to have heard so ill of thee
How sir so ill
So beyond detestable,
To be an honest vassal is some Calling,
Poor is the worst of that, shame Comes not to it,
But Mistress, that is the only Common bait:
Fortune sits at all our Catching whores with it,
And plucks them up by Clusters: there is my sword my Lord
And if your strong desires aim at my blood
Which runs too purely there, a nobler way
Quench it in mine
I near took sword in vain,
Hengist we here Create thee Earl of Kent
O that will do it, it will do it,
What ails our friend, look to him
O it is his Epilepsy, I know it well,
I holp him once in Germany, Comest again?
A virgins right hand strokes upon his heart
Gives him ease straight But it must be a pure virgin
Or ells it brings no Comfort
What a task
She puts upon herself un-urged for purity;
The proof of this will bring loves rage upon me
O this would mad a Woman, there is no plague
In love to indiscretion
Pish this Cures not
Dost think I will ever wrong thee
O most feelingly
But I will prevent it now, and break thy neck
With thine own Cunning, thou hast undertook
To give me help, to bring in royal Credited
Thy Cracked virginity, But I will spoil all;
I will not stand on purpose though I Could,
But fall still to disgrace thee
What you will not
I have no other way to help myself
For when thou art known to be a whore impostrous
I shall be sure to keep thee;
O sir shame me not
You have had what is precious, try my faith yet once more,
Undo me not at first in Chaste opinion
All this art shall not make me find my legs
I prithee: wilt thou willfully Confound me
Well I am Content for this time to recover
To save thy Credit, and bite in my pain,
But if thou ever failest me, I will fall
And thou shalt never get me up again
Agreed twixt you and I sir, see my Lord
A poor maids work: the Man may pass for health now,
Amongst the Clearest bloods and whose are nicest.
I have heard of women bring men on their knees
But few that ere restored them. how now Captain
My Lord methinks I Could do things past Man
I am so renewed in vigour, I Long most
For violent exercise to take me down
My joy is so high in Blood, I am above frailty
My Lord of Kent
Your Loves unworthy Creature
See-est thou this fair Chain, think upon the means
To keep it Linked forever
O my Lord
It is many degrees sundered from that hope
Besides your Grace has a young virtuous Queen
I say think on it, think on it?
If this wind hold!
I shall even fall
to my old disease again
There is no fault in thee But to Come so late,
All else is excellent; I Chide none But fate.
I have no Conceit now that
you ever loved me
But as lust held you for the time
So so;
Do you pine at my advancement sir
O Barrenness
Of understanding, what a right love is this
It is you that fall, I that am reprehended,
What height of honours eminence and fortune
Should ravish me from you,
Who Can tell that sir, what is he Can judge
Of a Man's appetite, before he sees him eat,
Who knows the strength of any's Constancy
That never yet was tempted.
we Can Call
Nothing our own;
if they be deeds to Come,
They are only ours when they are past and done?
How blessed are you above your apprehension
If your desire would lend you so much patience,
To examine the adventurous Condition
Of our affections, which are full of hazard,
And draw in the times goodness to defend us:
First this bold Course of ours Cannot last long
Or never does in any without shame,
And that you know Brings danger, and the greater
My father is in Blood, as he is well risen,
The greater will the storm of his rage be,
Against his Bloods wronging: I have Cast for this,
It is not advancement that I love alone
It is love of shelter to keep shame unknown.
O were I sure of thee, as it is impossible
There to be ever sure, where there is no hold,
Your pregnant hopes should not be long arising
By what assurance have you held me thus far
Which you found firm, despair you now in that
True, that was good security for the time
But admit a Change of state: when you are advanced
You women have a french toy in your pride
You make your friend Come Crouching, or perhaps
To bow in the hams the Better, he is put
To Complement three hours with your Chief Gentlewoman,
Then perhaps not admitted, nay nor never
That is the more noble fashion: forgetfulness
It is the pleasingest virtue
anyone Can have
That rises up from nothing, for by the same
Forgetting all, they forget from whence they Came
An excellent property for oblivion.
I pity all the fortunes of poor gentlewomen
Now in mine own unhappiness,
when we have given
All that we have to men, what is their requital,
An Ill faced Jealousy, which resembles much
The mistrustfulness of an insatiate thief,
That scarce believes he has all, though he has stripped
The true man naked, and left nothing on him
But the hard Cord that binds him: so are we
First robbed and then left bound with Jealousy;
Sure he that finds us now has a great purchase
And well he gains that builds another's ruins?
Yet man the only seed that is sown in envy
Whom Little would suffice as any Creature
Either in food or pleasure; yet it is known
What would give ten enough Contents not one.
A strong diseased Conceit, may tell strange tales to you
And so abuse us both: take but the opinion
Of Common reason, and you will find it impossible
That you should lose me in this kings advancement
Who here is a usurper, as he has the Kingdom
so shall he have my love by usurpation,
The right shall be in thee still; my ascension
To Dignity is but to waft thee upward
And all usurpers have a falling sickness
They Cannot keep up long,
May Credulous man
Putt all his Confidence in So weak a bottom
And make a saving voyage
Nay as gainful
As ever Man yet made,
Go take thy fortune,
Aspire with my Consent, so thy ambition
Will be sure to prosper; speak the fair Certainty
Of Britains Queen home to thy wishes
Speak
In hope I may but not in Certainty
I say in both, hope and be sure, I will quickly
Remove her that stands between thee and thy glory
Life is love;
If lost virginity Can wine such a day
I will have no daughter but shall learn my way
It will be good work for him that first instructs them
May be some son of mine, got by this woman too;
Man's scattered Lust brings forth most strange events,
If it were but strictly thought of; how many brothers
Wantonly got, through ignorance of their Births
May match with their own sisters:
peace it is he
Invention fail me not, it is a gallants Credited
To marry his whore bravely.
Have I power
Of life and death and Cannot Command ease
In mine own Blood: After I was a King
I thought I never should have felt pain more,
That there had been a ceasing of all passions
And Common stings which subjects use to feel,
That were Created with a patience fit
For all extremities; but such as we
Know not the way to suffer, then to do it
How most preposterous it is: what is all our greatness
If we that prescribe bounds to meaner men
Must not pass these ourselves, O most ridiculous,
This makes the vulgar merry to endure,
Knowing our state is strict, and less secure;
I will break through Custom, why should not the mind
The nobler part that is of us, be allowed
Change of Affections, as our bodies are
Still Change of food and raiment; I will have it so;
All fashions appear strange at first production
But this would be well followed: o Captain
My Lord I grieve for you, you scarce fetch breath
But a sigh hangs at end of it, this is no way
If you will give way to Council,
Set me right then
And quickly sir or I shall Curse thy Charity
For lifting up my understanding to me
To show that I was wrong, Ignorance is safe,
I slept happily, if knowledge mend me not
Thou hast Committed a most Cruel sin
To wake me into Judgment, and then leave me:
I will not leave you so sir that were rudely
First you have a flame too open and too violent
Which like blood guiltiness is an offender
Betrays him, when none Can, out with it sir
Or let some Cunning Coverture be made
Before our practise enters, it will spoil all else
Why look you sir I Can be as Calm as Silence
All the whiles music plays, strike on sweet friend,
As mild and merry as the heart of Innocence,
I prithee take my temper, has a virgin
A heat more modest,
He does well to ask me
I could have told that once: why here is a government,
There is not a sweeter amity in friendship
Than in this friendly league twixt you and health
Then since thou findest me Capable of happiness
Instruct me with the practise
What would you say my Lord
If I ensnare her in an act of Lust
O there were Art to the life, but that is impossible
I prithee flatter me no further with it;
Fie, so much sin as goes to make up that
Will near prevail with her; why I tell thee sir
She is so sin-killing modest, that if only
To move the question were enough adultery
To cause a separation, there is no gallant
So Brassy impudent, durst undertake
The words that should belong to it,
Say you so sir,
There is nothing made in the world, but has a way to it,
Though some be harder than the rest to find,
Yet one there is, that is Certain, and I think
I have took the Course to light on it
O I pray for it
I heard you lately say: from whence my Lord
My practise received light first, that your Queen
Still Consecrates her time to Contemplation,
Takes solitary walks
Nay late and early sir
Commands her weak guard from her, which are but women
When it is at strongest
I like all this well my Lord
And now your grace shall know what net is used
In many places to Catch modest women
Such as will never yield by prayers or gifts;
Now there are some will Catch up men as fast
But those she-fowlers nothing Concerns us
Their Birding is at windows, ours abroad
Where Ring-doves should be Caught, that is married Wives
Or Chaste maids, what the appetite has a mind too,
It is practised often, therefore worth discovery
And may well fit the purpose;
Make no pause then
The honest Gentlewoman, wherever she be
When nothing will prevail, I pity her now
Poor soul she is inticed forth by
her own sex,
To be betrayed to man; who in some garden house
Or remote walk taking his Lustful time
Binds darkness on her eyes, surprises her
And having a Coach ready turns her in
Hurrying her where he list for the sins safety
Making a rape of honour without words
And at the low ebbs of his Lust, perhaps
Some three days after, sends her Coached again
To the same place, and which would make most mad
She is spoiled of all, yet knows not where she was robbed
Wise dear precious mischief
Is this practised
Too much my Lord to be so little known
A spring to Catch a Maidenhead after sunset
Clip it and send it home again To the City
There it will be never perceived,
My raptures want expression, I Conceit
Enough to make me fortunate, and the great
Practise it then my Lord, -- I knew it would take

stage.l: Enter Castiza A Booke: two Ladyes:

sp.l: Methinks you live strange lives, when I see it not
The less it grieves me, you know how to ease me then,
If you but knew how well I loved your absence,
You would bestow it upon me without asking.
Faith for my part, were it not more for Ceremony
Than it is for Love, you should walk long enough
For my attendance, so think all my fellows
Though they say nothing: Books in woman's hands
They are as much against the hair methinks
As to see men work stomachers and night-rails?
She that has the green sickness and should follow her Council
would die like an ass, and go to the worms like a salad;
not I as long as such a Creature as man is made, she is
a fool that will not know what he is good for
Though amongst lives elections that of virgin
I speak noblest, yet it has pleased Just heaven
To send me a Contented Blessedness
In this of marriage which
I ever doubted:
I see the Kings affection was a true one
It Lasts and holds out long, that is no mean virtue
In a Commanding Man, though in great fear
At first I was enforced to venture on it,
All is happy Clear and safe,
The rest Comes gently then,
Be sure you seize on her full sight at first
For fear of my discovery
I will not miss it
Now fortune and I am sped
O help Treason Treason
Sirrah how stand you, prevent noise and Clamour
Or death shall end thy service
A sure Cunning
O rescue
Dead her voice, away, make speed
No help no succour
Louder yet, extend
Your voice to the last wrack, you shall have leave now,
You are far from any pity,
What is my sin
Contempt of man and he is a noble Creature
And takes it in ill part to be despised
I never despised any
No? you hold us
Unworthy to be Loved, what Call you that.
I have a Lord disproves you,
Pish your Lord,
You are bound to love your Lord,
that is no thanks to you,
You should love those you are not tied to Love,
That is the right trial of a Woman's Charity
I know not what you are nor what my fault is
But if it be life you seek, whatever you be,
Use no immodest words, and take it from me:
You kill me more in talking sinfully
Than acting Cruelly, be so far pitiful
To end me without words;
Long may you live
The wish of a good subject, it is not life
That I thirst after, loyalty forbid
I should Commit such Treason, you mistake me
I have no such bloody thought,
only your Love
Shall Content me
What said you sir
Thus, thus, plainly
To strip my words as naked as my purpose,
I must and will enjoy you; gone already!
Look to her, Bear her up, she goes apace;
I feared this still, and therefore Came provided,
There is that will fetch life from a dying spark
and make it spread a furnace; she is well straight,
It kept a Lord seven years alive together
In spite of nature, that he looked like one
Had leave to walk out of a grave to air himself,
Yet still walked Lord; pish let her go, she stands
Upon my knowledge, or else she Counterfeits,
I know the virtue;
Never did sorrows in afflicted Woman
Meet with such Cruelty, such hardhearted ways
Human invention never found before:
To Call back life to live, is but ill taken
Of some departing soul, then to force mine back
To an eternal act of death in lust,
What is it but most execrable.
But this is from the business, list to me
Here you are now far from all hope of friendship
Save what you make mine, scape me you Cannot
Send your soul that assurance; that resolved on
You know not who I am, nor never shall
I need not fear you then; But give Consent
Then with the faithfulness of a true friend
I will open myself to you, fall your servant
As I do now in hope, proud of submission
And seal the deed up with eternal secrecy
Not death should pick it open, much less the kings
Authority or Torture,
I admire him
O sir, whatever
you are, I teach my knee
Thus to requite you, Be Content to take
Only my sight as ransom for mine honour,
And where you have but mocked mine eyes with darkness
Pluck them out quite, all outward light of body
I will spare most willingly, But take not from me
That which must guide me to another world
And leave me dark forever, fast without
That Cursed pleasure which would make two souls
Endure a famine everlastingly:
This almost moves
By this light he will be taken
I will wrestle down all pity, will you Consent;
I will never be so guilty
Farewell words then
You hear no more of me, But thus I Seize thee
O if a power above be reverenced in thee
I bind thee by that name, by manhood, nobleness
And all the Charms of honour
Here is one Caught
For an example; never was poor Lady
So mocked into false terror: with what anguish
She lies with her own Lord,
now she Could Curse
All into barrenness and beguile herself by it;
Conceit is a powerful thing, and is indeed
Placed as a palate, to taste grief or love
And as that relishes, so we approve;
Hence it Comes that our taste is so beguiled
Changing pure blood, for some that is mixed, and soiled
A fair and fortunate Constellation reigned
When we set footing here; from his first gift
Which to a Kings unbounded eyes seemed nothing,
(The Compass of a hide) I have erected
A strong and spacious Castle, yet Contained myself
Within my limits without Check or censure:
Thither with all the observance of a subject
(The liveliest witness of a grateful mind)
I purpose to invite him and his Queen
And feast them nobly.
We will enter sir;
It is a state business of a twelve-month Long
The choosing of a Mayor
What noise is that
Sir we must speak with the good Earl of Kent;
Though we were never
brought up to keep a door
We are as honest sir as some that do
Now what is the occasion of their Clamours sir
Please you my Lord a Company of townsmen,
Are bent against all denials and resistance
To have speech with your Lordship, and that you
Must end a difference, which none else Can do
Why then there is reason in their violence
Which I never looked for; let in first but one,
And as we relish him, the rest Comes on,
It were no safe wisdom in a rising Man
To slight of such as these, nay rather these
Are the foundation of a Lofty work;
We Cannot build without them and stand sure;
He that ascends up to a Mountains top
My first begin at foot, now sir who Comes
They Cannot yet agree my Lord of that
How
They say it is worse now for them
than ever it was before
For where the difference stood but between two
Upon this Coming first, they are at odds,--
One says sir he shall lose his place at Church by it
Another he will not do his wife that wrong,
And by their good wills, they would Come all at first,
The strife Continues in most heat my Lord
Between a Country Barber and a tailor,
Of the same parish, and which your Lordship names
It is yielded by Consent that one shall enter.
Here is no sweet coil, I am glad they are grown so reasonable
Call in the Barber, if the tale be long
He will Cut it short I trust, that is all the hope of it
Now sir are you the Barber
O most Barbarous: a Corrector of enormities in hair
my Lord, a promoter of upper lips, or what your Lordship.
in the neatness of your discretion shall vouchsafe to Call it.
Very good: I see this you have without Book,
But what is your Business now,
Your Lordship: Comes
To a high point indeed, the business sir
Lies all about the head
That is work for you
No my good Lord; there is a Corporation a kind of body, a body.
The Barber is out at body, let in the Taylor,
This it is to reach beyond your
own profession;
When you let go your head, you lose your memory,
You have no business with the body
Yes, sir I am a Barber surgeon, I have had something to
do with it in my time my Lord, and I was never so out
of the body as I have been here of late; send me good luck;
I will go marry some whore or other But I will get in again.
Now sir a good discovery Come from you
That we may know the inwards of the Business
I will rip up the lining to your Lordship
And show what stuff it is made on, for the Body
Or Corporation
There the Barber left indeed
It is pieced up of two factions
A patched town the whilst
Nor Can we go through stitch my noble Lord
The Collar is so great in the one party,
And as in linsey woolsey wove together
One piece makes several suites, so upright Earl
our linsey woolsey hearts makes all this Coil.
What is all this now
Call in the rest I am never the wiser yet
I should Commend my wit Could I but guess
What this would Come to, now sirs what are you
Sir reverence of your Lordship I am a glouer
What needs that then
Sometimes I deal with dogs Leather
Sir reverence all that while
Well to the purpose if there be any towards
I were an ass else, saving your Lordship's pleasure, we have
A body but our Town wants a hand, a hand of Justice,
a worshipful Master Mayor.
This is well handed yet,
A man may take some hold on it, you want a Mayor
Right, but there is two at fisticuffs about it sir
As I may say at daggers drawing sir
But that I Cannot say because they have none
And you being Earl of Kent, the Town does say
Your Lordship's voice shall Choose and part the fray.
This is strange work for me, well sir what be they
The one is a Tanner
Fie I shall be too partial
I owe too much affection to that trade
To put it to my voice: what is his name
Symon sir
How symon too
Nay it is but Symon one sir: the very same Symon
That sold your Lordship: the Hide
What sayst thou
That is all his glory sir, he got his Mistress widow by it presently
after, a rich tanners wife, she has set him up, he was her
foreman a long time in her other husbands days
Now let me perish in my first aspiring
If the pretty simplicity of his fortune
Does not most highly take me, it is a presage methinks
Of bright succeeding happiness To mine
When my fates glowworm Casts forth such a shine:
And what is the other that Contends with him
Marry my noble Lord a fustian weaver
How, will he offer to Compare with symon
He a fit match for him
Hark, hark, my Lord
Here they Come both now in a pelting Chase
From the Town house
How, before me, I scorn thee,
Thou wattle-faced singed pig
Pig, I defy thee,
My uncle was a Jew and scorned the motion.
I list not brook thy vaunts, Compare with me
Thou spindle of Concupiscence, it is well known
Thy first wife was a flax wench.
But such a flax wench
Would I might never want at my most need
Nor any friend of mine, my neighbours knew her,
Thy wife was but a hempen halter to her
Use better words, I will hang thee in my year else,
Let whose will Choose thee afterwards
Peace for shame,
Quench your great spirits, do you not see his Lordship
What Master Symonides
Symonides what a fine name he has made of Symon; then
he is an ass that Calls me Symon again; I am quite out of love
with it.
Give me thy hand; I love thee and thy fortunes,
I like a man that thrives.
I took a Widow my Lord to be the best piece of ground to thrive
on, and By my faith there is a young Symonides like a green
onion peeping up already
Thou hast a good lucky hand
I have somewhat sir
But why to me is this election offered
The Choosing of a Mayor goes by most voices
True sir but most of our townsmen are so hoarse with drinking
there is never a good voice amongst
them all that are now here in this
Are you Content both to putt all to these then
To whom I liberally resign my interest
To prevent Censure
I speak first my Lord
Though I speak Last, I hope I am not least,
If they will Cast away a Town born Child
They may, it is but dying some forty years or so
Before my time
I will leave you to your Choice awhile
Your good Lordship
Look you neighbours view us both well ere you be too hasty, let
Oliuer the fustian Weaver stand as fair as I do, and the
Devil give him good of it
I do thou upstart Callimoocher I do, it is well known to
thee I have been twice Ale-conner, thou mushrump, that
shot up in one night with Lying with thy Mistress
Faith thou art such a spiny Baldrib, all the
Mistresses in the Town would never get thee up
I scorn to rise by a Woman as thou didst:
My wife shall rise by me
The Better for some of thy neighbours when you are asleep
I pray Cease of your Communication we Can do nothing
ells.
I gave that Barber a fustian suit, and twice redeemed
his Citron, he may remember me
I fear no false measure but in that Taylor, the glouer
and the Buttonmonger are both Cocksure,
That Colliers eye I like not,
Now they Consult, the matter is abrewing
Poor Gill my wife lies Longing for this news,
It will make her a glad mother
A symon, a symon, a symon, a symon.
My good people I thank you all.
Wretch that I am; Tanner thou hast Curried favour
I Currye; I defy thy fustian fume
But I will prove a rebel all thy year
And raise up the seven deadly sins against thee
The deadly sins will scorn to rise with thee
If they have any breeding -- as Commonly they
are well brought up, it is not for every scab
to be acquainted with them; But leaving scabs, to you
good neighbours now I bend my speech first to say
more than a Man Can say, I hold it not so fit
to be spoken, But to say what man ought to say
there I leave you also; I must Confess that your
loves have Chosen a weak and unlearned man, that
I Can neither write nor read you all Can witness,
yet not altogether so unlearned, but I Could set my
mark to a bond, if I would be so simple, an excellent
Token of government; cheer you then my hearts, you have
done you know not what, there is a full point, you must all cough
and hem now,
hum hum hum Cough
Now touching our Common adversary the fustian weaver who
threateneth he will raise the deadly sins amongst us, which as
I take it are seven in number, let them Come, our town is big
enough to hold them, we will not much disgrace it; Besides you know
a deadly sin will lie in a narrow hole, But when they think
themselves safest and the webb of their iniquity woven, with
the horse strength of my Justice I will break the looms of their
Concupiscence, and let the weaver go seek his shuttle, here
you may hem again if you will do me the favour
Cough and hem
Why I thank you, and it shall not go unrewarded: now for the
seven deadly sins, first for pride which always sits uppermost
and will be placed without a Church-warden, Being a sin that is
not like to be Chargeable to the parish, I slip it over and
think it not worthy of punishment: now you all know
that sloth does not anything, this place you see requires
wisdom, how Can a man in Conscience punish that which
does nothing: Envy a poor lean Creature that eats raw
liver, perhaps it pines to see me Chosen, and that makes
me the fatter with laughing, if I punish envy then I punish
mine own Carcass,
a great sin against authority: for wrath,
the less we say, the better it is, a scurvy desperate thing it is that
Commonly hangs itself and saves Justice many a
halter by it; now for Covetousness and Gluttony, I will tell
you more when I Come out of mine office, I shall have
time to try what they are: I will prove them soundly,
and if I find Covetousness and Gluttony to be directly
sins, I will bury of in the bottom of a Chest, and the other in the
end of my garden, But sirs for Lechery, I mean to
tickle that home; nay I am resolved upon it, I will not
leave one whore in all the town.
Some of your neighbours may go seek their wives in the
Country then
Barber be silent, I will Cut thy Comb else; to Conclude, I
will learn the villainies of all trades,
mine own I
know already, if there be any knavery in the Baker I
will bowl it out, if in the Brewer I will taste him
thoroughly, and then piss out his inquiry
in his own
sinkhole; in a word I will knock out all enormities
like a Bullock, and send the hide to my fellow tanners.
A Symonides a true symonides indeed.
How now how goes your choice
Here is he my Lord
You may prove I am the man, I am bold to take
the upper hand of your Lordship: a little, I will not lose an
inch of mine honour
Hold sirs there is some few Crowns to mend your feast
Because I like your Choice
Joy bless your Lordship:
We will drink your health with trumpets
Aye with sackbuts
That is the more solemn drinking for my state
No malt this year shall fume into my pate
Continues still that fervour in his Love
Nay with increase my Lord the flame grows greater
Though he has learned a Better art of late
To set a screen before it.
Canst speak low
Heard every word my lord
Distinctly;
The Course I took was dangerous but not failing
For I Conveyed myself behind the hangings,
Even first before her entrance.
It was well ventured
I had such a woman's first and second longing in me
To hear how she would bear her mocked abuse
After she was half returned to privacy,
I Could have fasted out an ember week
And never thought of hunger to have heard her:
She fetched three short turns, I shall near forget them,
Like an imprisoned lark that offers still
Her wing at liberty and returns checked,
so would her soul fain have been gone, and even hung
Fluttering upon the bars of poor mortality,
Which ever as it offered, drove her back again
Then Came your holy Lupus and Germanus,
O two holy Confessors
At whose sight
I Could perceive her fall upon her Breast
And Cruelly afflict herself with sorrow:
I never heard a sigh till I heard hers,
Who after her Confession pitying her
Putt her into a way of patience,
Which now she holds to keep it hid from you,
There is all the pleasure that I took in it now
When I heard that my pains was well remembered
So with applying Comforts and relief
They have brought it low now to an easy grief.
But yet the taste is not quite gone.
Still fortune
Sits bettering our invention
Here She Comes
Yonder is my Lord: O I will return again
Methinks I should not dare to look on him
She is gone again
It works the kindlier sir
Go now and Call her back: she winds herself
Into the snare so prettily, it is a pleasure
To set toils for her,
He may read my shame,
Now in my blush
Come you are so linked to holiness
So taken up with Contemplative desires
That the world has you, yet enjoys you not
You have been weeping too
Not I my Lord
Trust me I fear you have: you are much to blame
And you should yield so to passion without Cause,
Is not there time enough for meditation,
Must it lay title to your health and Beauty,
And draw them into times Consumation too.
It is too exacting for a holy faculty;
My Lord of Kent, I pray wake him Captain
He reads himself asleep sure
My Lord
Your pardon sir
Nay I will take away your Book, and bestow it here,
Lady, you that delight in virgins stories
And all Chaste works, here is excellent reading for you,
Make of that book, as raised men make a favour
Which they grow sick to part from; and now my Lord
You that have so Conceitedly gone beyond me
And made such large use of a slender gift
Which we never minded, I Commend your thrift
And for your buildings name shall to all ages
Carry the stamp and impress of your wit
It shall be Called thong castle
How my Lord
Thong castle there your Highness quits me kindly
It is fit art should be known by her right name,
You that Can spread my gift I will spread your fame
I thank your grace for that sir
And loved Lord
So well we do accept thy invitation
With all speed we will set forward
Your love honours me

stage.l: two Ladyes Roxena Devon: Staff: at one Doore Symon
And his Brethren at the other

sp.l: Lo I the Mayor of Quinborough town by name
With all my Brethren, saving one that is Lame
Are Come as fast, as fiery mill-horse gallops,
To meet thy Grace, thy Queen and thy fair trollops:
For reason of our Coming do not look
It must be done, I found it in the town Book,
And yet not I myself, I scorn to reed
I keep a Clark to do these jobs for need;
And now expect a rare Conceit before thong castle see thee
Reach me the thing to give the King, the other too I prithee
Now here they be for Queen and thee, the gifts all steel and leather,
But the Conceit of mickle weight, and here they are Come together,
To show two loves must join in one, our town presents to thee
This gilded scabbard to the Queen, this dagger unto thee:
Forbear your tedious and ridiculous duties
I hate them as I do the rotten roots of you
You inconstant rabble, I have felt your fits,
Sheath up your Bounty with your Iron wits
And get you gone
Look sirs is his back turned
It is it is
Then bless the good Earl of Kent say I
I will have this dagger turned into a pie
And eaten up for anger every Bit of it
and when that pie is new Cut up by some rare Cunning pie man
They shall all lamentably sing put up thy dagger symon

stage.l: Hoboys the King and his traine mett by Hengist and Hersus
they salute and Exevnt; while the Banquet is Brought forth
Musique playes, Enter Vortig: Hors, Dev: Staff: Castiza Roxena

sp.l: A Welcome mighty Lord may appear Costlier
More full of talk and toil, show and Conceit,
But one more stored with thankful love and truth
I forbid all the sons of men to boast of
Why here is a Fabric that implies eternity,
The Building plain but most substantial,
Methinks it looks as if it mocked all ruin
Save the great Masterpiece of Consumation,
The end of time, which must Consume even ruin
And eat that into Cinders
There is no Brass
Would last your praise my Lord; It would last beyond it,
And shame our most durable mettle
Hersus
My Lord
This is the time I have Chosen, here is a full meeting
And here will I disgrace her
It will be sharp my Lord
O it will be best sir.
Why here is the Earl her father
Aye and the Lord her Uncle, that is the height of it,
Invited both apurpose to rise sick
Full of shames surfeit
And that is shrewd By our lady
It ever sticks Close to the ribs of honour
Great men are never sound men after it,
It leaves some ache or other in their names still
Which their posterity feels at every weather,
Mark but the least presentment of occasion
As such times yields enough, and then mark me.
My observance is all yours, you know it my Lord;
What Careful ways some take to abuse themselves,
But as there be assurers of men's goods
Against storm or pirate, which gives venturers Courage,
so such there must be to make up man's theft,
Or there would be no woman venturer left.
See now they find their seats, what a false knot
Of amity he ties about her arm
Which rage must part, in marriage it is no wonder
Knots knit with kisses are oft broke with thunder
Music then I have done, I always learn
To give my betters place
Where is Captain Hersus
My Lord
Sit sit we will have a health anon
To all good services
They are poor in these days
They had rather have the Cup than the health my Lord
I sit wrong now, he hears me not, and most
Great men are deaf on that side.
If in music were a power
To breath a welcome to thy worth
This should be the ravishing hour
To vent her spirits treasure forth;
Welcome O welcome, in that word alone
She would choose to dwell and draw all parts to one.
My Lord of Kent I thank you for this welcome
It Came unthought of in the sweetest language
That ever my soul released
You are pleased my Lord
To raise my happiness from slight deservings
To show what power is in prices: not in us
Aught worthy, it is in you that makes us thus
I am Chiefly sad my Lord, your Queen is not merry
So honour bless me, he has found the way
to my grief strangely: is there no delight,
My Lord I wish not any, nor is it needful;
I am as I was ever
That is not so
How O my fears
When she writ Maid my Lord
You knew her otherwise
To speak but truth,
I never knew her
a great friend to mirth,
Nor taken much with any one delight
Though there be many seemly and honourable:
To give Content to Ladies without taxing
My Lord of Kent, this to thy full desert
Which intimates thy higher flow to honour,
Which like a river shall return service
To the great Master fountain
Where is your Lord
I missed him not till now Lady? and yours,
No marvel then we were so out of the way
Of all pleasant discourse, they are the keys
Of human Music, sure at their nativities
Great nature signed a general patent to them,
To take up all the mirth in a whole Kingdom,
What is their employment now,
May it please your grace
We never are so far acquainted with them
Nothing we know, But what they Cannot keep
That is even the fashion of them all my Lord
It seems you have great faith though in their Constancy,
And they in yours, you dare so trust each other,
Hope well we do my Lord, we have reason for it
Because they say Brown men are honestest,
But she is a fool will swear for any Colour
They would for yours
Troth it is a doubtful question
And I would be loath to put mine to it my Lord
Faith dare you swear for yourselves that is a plain motion.
My Lord
You cannot deny that with honour
And since it is urged I will put you to it in troth
May it please your grace
It will please me wondrous well
And here is a book, mine never goes without one
She is an example to you all for purity,
Come swear, I have sworn you shall: that you never knew
The will of any man Besides your Husbands
I will swear my Lord as far as my remembrance
How your remembrance, that were strange
Your grace,
Hearing our Just excuses will not say so
Well what is your Just excuse, you are
never without some
I am often taken with a sleep my Lord
The loudest thunder Cannot waken me
Not if a Cannons Burthen were discharged
Close by mine ear, the more may be my wrong;
There can be no infirmity my Lord
That is more excusable in any woman
And I am so trouble with the Mother too
I have often Called in help, I know not whom
Three at once has been too weak to keep me down
I perceive there is no fasting: well fare on then
deceives faiths Anchor of her hold
Come at all seasons: here: be thou the star
To guide those erring women: show the way
Which I will make them follow: why dost start
Draw back and look so pale;
My Lord
Come hither
Nothing but take that oath, thou wilt take a thousand
A thousand, poor, a million, nay as many
As there be Angels registers of oaths:
Why look their over-holy fearful Chastity
That sins in nothing but in too much niceness
I will begin first and swear for thee myself,
I know thee a perfection so unstained
So sure so absolute, I will not pant on it
But Catch time greedily: by all these blessings
That blows truth into fruitfulness, and those Curses
That with their barren Breaths Blast perjury
Thou art as pure as sanctity's best shrine
From all man's mixture, But what is Lawful: mine.
O heaven forgive him, has forsworn himself,
Come it is but going now my way
That is bad enough
I have Cleared all doubts you see
Good my Lord spare me
How, it grows later now, then so
For modesties sake make more speed this way
Pardon me my Lord: I Cannot
What
I dare not
Fail all Confidence
In thy weak kind forever.
Here is a storm
Able to wake all of our name inhumed
And raise them from their sleeps of peace and fame
To set the honour of their Bloods right here
Hundred years after, a perpetual motion
Has their true glory been from seed to seed,
And Cannot be Choked now with a poor grain
Of Dust and earth; we that remain my Lord
Her uncle and myself, in this wild tempest,
As ever robbed man's peace, will undertake
Upon lives deprivation, lands and honour,
She shall accept this oath.
You do but call me then
Into a world of more despair and horror;
Yet since so wilfully you stand engaged
In high scorn to be touched, with expedition
Perfect your undertakings with your fames,
Or by the Issues of abused belief
I will take the forfeit of lives, lands and honour,
And make one ruin serve our Joys and yours.
Why here is a height of misery never reached yet
I lose myself and others
You may see
How much we lay in Balance with your goodness
And had we more it went, for we presume
You Cannot be religious and so vild
As to forswear myself: it is true my Lord
I will not add a voluntary sin
To a Constrained one, I Confess great sir
The honour of your Bed has been abused
O beyond patience
Give me hearing sir
But far from my Consent: I was surprised
By villains and so ravished
Hear you that sirs
O Cunning texture to enclose adultery
Mark but what subtle vail her sin puts on;
Religion brings her to Confession first,
Then steps in Art, to sanctify that Lust,
It is likely you Could be surprised
My Lord
I will hear no more, our guard: Seize on those lords
We Cannot perish now too fast, make speed
Swift to destruction, he breathes most accursed
That lives so long to see his name die first
Ha ha, here is no dear villainy
Let him entreat sir
That falls in saddest grief for this event
Which ill begins the fortune of this Building:
My Lord
What if he should Cause me to swear too Captain
You know sir I am as far to seek in honesty
As the worst here Can be, I should be shamed too:
Why fool, they swear by that we worship not
So you may swear your heart out,
and never hurt yourself
That was well thought of, I would quite lost myself,
You shall prevail in noble suites my Lord
But this -- this shames the speaker
I will step in now
Though it shall be to no purpose: good my Lord
Think on your noble and most hopeful issue
Lord Vortiner the prince
A Bastard sir
O that his life were in my fury now
That injury stirs my soul to swear the Truth
Of his Conception. here I take the book my Lord
By all the glorified rewards of virtue
And prepared punishments for Consents in sin,
A Queens hard sorrow never supplied a Kingdom
With issue more Legitimate than Vortiner
Pish this takes not out the stain of present shame though
To be once good, is nothing when it Ceases,
Continuance Crowns desert, she Can never go
For perfect honest that is not always so
Beshrew this needless urging of this oath
It has Justified her somewhat
To small purpose sir
Amongst so many women not one here
Dare swear a simple Chastity, here is an age
To propagate virtue in, since I have began it
I will shame you altogether, and so leave you?
My Lord of Kent
Your Highness
That is your daughter
Yes my good Lord
Though I am your guest today
And should be less austere to you or yours
In this case pardon me, I will not spare her
Then her own goodness
friend her: here she Comes my Lord
The tender reputation of a maid
Makes up your honour, or ells nothing Can
The oath you take, is not for truth to man
But to your own
white soul, a mighty Task;
What dare you do in this,
My Lord as much
As Chastity Can put a woman to
I ask no favour, and to approve the purity
Of what my habit and my time professes,
As also to requite all Courteous censure
Here I take oath I am as free from man
As truth from death, or sanctity from stain
O thou treasure, that ravishes the possessor,
I know not where to speed so well again
I will keep thee while I have thee: here is a fountain
To spring forth Princes and the seed of Kingdoms;
Away with that infection of great Honour
And those her leprous pledges, By her poison
Blemished and spotted in their fames forever;
Here we will restore succession with true peace
And of pure virgins grace the poor increase.
Ha ha: he is well provided now, here struck my fortune
With what an impudent Confidence she swore honest,
Having the advantage of the oath: the mischiefs
That people a lost honour: O they are infinite
For as at a small Breach in town or Castle
When one has entrance, a whole Army follows,
In Woman, so abusively once known,
Thousands of sins has passage made with one:
Vice Comes with tropes, and they that entertain
A mighty potentate must receive his train.
Methinks I should not hear from fortune next
Under an Earldom now, she Cannot spend
A night so Idly, but to make a Lord
With ease, methinks and play; the Earl of Kent
Is Calm and smooth, like a deep dangerous water,
He has some secret way, I know his Blood
The grave is not greedier, nor hells Lord more proud
Somewhat will hap, for this astonishing choice
Strikes pale the Kingdom at which I rejoice

stage.l: Hoboyes Dumb show Enter Lupus Germanus Devon Staffo: Leading
Vortiner they seate him in the throne and Crowne him King, Enter
Vortiger in greate passion and submission, they neglect him, then
Roxena expressing greate fury and discontent, they leade out
Vortiner, and leaue Vortiger and Roxena; she subornes> two
saxons to murder Vortiner, they sweare performance and
secresie and Exit with Roxena, then Vortiger left alone draws
his sword and offers to run himself thereon Enter Hersus and
prevents him, then the Lordes Enter again and Exit Hersus, then
is brought in the Bodye of Vortiner in a Chaire dead, they all
in amazemt and sorrow take Vortiger and upon his submission
restore him, sweareing him against the saxons, then
Enter Hengist with diuers saxons: Vortiger and the rest
with their swordes drawn threaten their expulsion: whereat
Hengist amazd, sendes one to entreate
a peaceable parly, which seemeing to be granted by laying down
their weapons Exevnt seuerally Enter Raynulph.

sp.l: Of Pagan Blood a Queen being Chose
Roxena high, the Britains rose
And Vortiner they Crowned King;
But she soon poisoned that sweet spring;
Then to rule they did restore
Vortiger and him they swore
Against the saxons, they Constrained
Begged peace-treaty -- and obtained:
And now in numbers equally
Upon the plain near salsbury
A peaceful meeting they decree
Like men of love no weapon seen.
But Hengist that Ambitious Lord
Full of guile Corrupts his word;
As the sequel too well proves
On that your eyes, on us your Loves.
If we let slip this opportuneful hour
