Take leave of fortune, Certainty or thought
Of ever fixing: we are loose at root
And the least storm may rend us from the bosom
Of this Lands hopes forever: But dear saxons
Fasten we now, and our unshaken firmness
Will assure after ages
We are resolved my Lord
Observed you not how Vortiger the King
Base in submission threatened our expulsion,
His arm held up against us? is it not time
To make our best prevention's, what should Check me?
Has perfected that great work in our Daughter
And made her Queen, she Can ascend no higher,
Nor Can the insistent flow of his Loves praises
Which yet still sways, take from that height it raises:
She is sure enough: what rests then but that I
Make happy mine own hopes; and policy
Forbids no way, noble or treacherous ended,
What best effects is of her best Commended:
Therefore be quick, dispatch, here every man
Receive into thee service of his vengeance
An instrument of steel, which will unseen,
Lurk like the snake under the innocent shade
Of a spread summers leaf; and as great substance
Blocks itself up into less room in gold
Than other metals, and less Burdensome
so in the other hand lies all Confined
Full as much Death as ever changed mankind;
It is all the same time that a small watch shows
As great Church dials, and as true as those,
Take heart the Commons Loves us: those removed
That are his nerves, our greatness stands improved
Give us the word my Lord, and we are perfect
That is true the word, I lose myself, nemp your Sexes,
It shall be that,
Enough sir then we strike
But the King is mine, take heed you touch not him
We shall not be at leisure never fear it
We shall have work enough of
our own my Lord
They Come, Calm looks But stormy souls possess you
We see you keep your word in all points firm
No Longer may we boast of so much Breath
As goes to a words making, then of Care
In the preserving of it when it is made
You are in a virtuous way my Lord of Kent
And since we are both sides well met like sons of peace
All other arms Laid by in sign of favour
If our Conditions be embraced,
They are they are
We will use no other but these only here
Nemp your sexes
Treason Treason
Follow to the heart
My Trusty saxons, it is your liberty
Your wealth and honour; soft you are mine my Lord
Take me not Basely when all sense and strength
Lies bound up in amazement, at this treachery,
What Devil hath Breathed this everlasting part
Of falsehood into thee?
Let it suffice
I have you and will hold you prisoner
As fast as death holds your best props in silence:
We know the hard Conditions of our peace,
Slavery or diminution which we hate
With a joint loathing: may all perish thus
That seek to subjugate or lessen us.
O you strange nooks of guile and subtlety
Where man so Cunningly lies hid from man
Who Could expect such treason from your breast
Such Thunder from your voice: or take you pride
To imitate the fair uncertainty,
Of a Bright day that Teems the suddenest storm,
When the world least expects one: but of all
I will never trust
fair sky in man again
There is the deceitful weather: will you heap
More guilt upon you, By detaining me,
Like a Cup taken after a full surfeit,
Even in Contempt
of health, and heaven together?
What seek you
Ransom for your liberty
As I shall like of, or you near obtain it
Here is a most headstrong dangerous ambition;
Sow you the seeds of your aspiring hopes
In Blood and treason, and must I pay for them.
Have not I raised you to this height.
My Lord
A work of mine own
merit since you enforce it
There is even the general thanks of all aspirers:
When they have all the honours Kingdoms Can impart
They write above it still their
I have writ mine true my Lord
That is all their sayings
Have I not raised your daughter to a Queen
Why you have the harmony of your pleasure for it
You have Crowned your own
desires; what is that to me.
And what will Crown yours sir
Faith things of reason,
I demand Kent
Why you have the Earldom of it
The Kingdom of it I meant, without Control,
The full possession
This is strange in you
It seems you are not acquainted with my blood yet
To Call this strange;
Never was King of Kent yet
But who was general King
I will be the first then,
Everything has beginning
No less title
Not if you hope for liberty my Lord
So dear a happiness would be wrong by slighting
Well take it, I resign it
Why I thank your grace
Is your great thirst sufficed yet
Faith my Lord
There is yet behind a pair of teeming sisters
Norfolke and Suffolke, and I have done with you
You have got a fearful thirst my Lord of late
However you Came by it
It behoves me then
For my Bloods health to seek all means to quench it
Them too
There is nothing will be abated sir.
Put your assurance in it
You have the advantage,
He whom fate Captivates must yield to all
Take them,
And you your liberty and peace my Lord
With our best love and wishes: here is an hour
Begins us Saxons, in wealth fame and power.
Are these the noblest fruits and fairest requital's
From works of our own raising;
Methinks the murder of Constantius
Speaks to me in the voice of it, and the wrongs
Of our late Queen slipped both into one Organ
Here is no safety for me, but what is most doubtful
The Rank rout love me not, and the strength I had
This foul devouring Treachery has demolished;
Ambition, hell, mine own undoing Lust,
And all the brood of plagues Conspire against me
I have not a friend left me.
My Lord he dies
That says it But yourself, wert that thief King
That has so boldly stolen his honours from you,
A Treason that wrings tears from honest manhood
So rich am I now in thy love and pity
I feel no loss at all; But we must part
My Queen and I to Cambria
My Lord
And I not named that have vowed Lasting service
To lives extremest minute to your fortunes?
Is my ruined fate blessed with so dear a friend
My Lord not space in Earth, nor Breadth in sea
Shall divide me from you.
O faithful treasure
All my lost happiness is made up in thee.
I will follow you through the world, to Cuckold you
That is my way now;
everyone has his toy
While he lives here: some men delight in Building,
A trick of Babel and will never be left,
Some in Consuming what was raised with toiling
Hengist is getting honour, I in spoiling
Is not that Rebel Oliuer the fustian weaver
That Traitor to my year apprehended yet
Not yet so please your worship
Not yet sayst thou;
How darest thou say not yet, and see me present,
Thou malapert Clark,
That is good for nothing but to write and read,
Is his loom Seized on.
Yes if it like your worship
and sixteen yards of fustian
Good; let a yard be saved to mend me between the legs, the
rest Cut in pieces and given to the poor, it is heretic
fustian and should be burnt indeed, But being worn
thread bare, the shame will be as great, how think you
Greater methinks the Longer it is wore
Where being once Burnt, it Can be burned no more
True wise and most senseless, how now sirrah
What is he approaching here in dusty pumps
and greasy hair
A footman sir to the great King of Kent
The King of Kent, shake him by the hand for me
Footman, thou art welcome, lo my deputy shakes thee;
Come when my year is out and I will do it myself,
If it were a dog Come from the King of Kent,
I keep those officers would shake him I trow;
And what is the news with thee thou well stewed footman,
The king my Master
With a few saxons
Intends this night to make merry with you
Merry with me, I should be sorry else fellow
And take it in evil part, so tell Kents King
Why was I Chosen Mayor, But that great men
Should make merry with me, there is a Jest indeed
Tell him I looked for it, and me much he wrongs
If he forget symon that Cut out his thongs.
I will run with your worship's answer
Do I prithee;
That fellow will be roasted against supper,
He is half enough already: his brows baste him:
The King of Kent, the King of Christendom
Shall not be better welcome to me,
For you must imagine now neighbours this is
The time that Kent stands out of Christendom
For he that is King there
now was never Christened;
This for your more instruction I thought fit
That when you are dead you may teach your Children wit
Clark
At your worship's elbow
I must turn you
From the hall into the Kitchen tonight,
Give order that twelve Pigs be roasted yellow,
Nine geese and some three Larks for piddling meat,
But twenty wood Cocks, I will bid all my neighbours:
Give Charge the mutton Come in all blood raw;
That is Infidel meat? the King of Kent is a Pagan
and must be served so; and let those officers
That seldom or never go to Church bring it in,
It will be well taken; run: Come hither you now;
Take all the Cushions down and thwack them soundly
After my feast of millers; for their Buttocks
Has left a peck of flower in them, Beat them Carefully
Over a bolting hutch, there will be enough
For a pan pudding as your dame will handle it;
Then putt fresh water into both the bow pots,
And burn a little Juniper in the Hall Chimney,
Like a beast as I was I pissed out the fire Last night
and never thought of the Kings Coming: how now
Returned so quickly.
Please your worship there is a Certain Company of players.
Ha players
Country Comedians, Interluders sir, desire your worships
leave and favour to enact in the Town Hall
In the town hall: it is ten to one
I never grant it, Call
them before my worship, if my house will not serve
their turn I would fain see the proudest he lend a
Barn to them: now sirs are you Comedians
We are anything sir: Comedians Tragedians
Tragicomedians, Come-tragedians, pastoralists
humorists, Clowns and satirists, we have them sir
from the smile to the laugh; from the laugh to the handkercher
You are very strong in the wrists: and shall these good
parts you are endued withal, be cast away among peddlers
and malt-man,
For want of better Company if it please your worship.
What think you of me my masters: have you
audacity enough to play before so high a person:
will not my Countenance daunt you, for if you play
before me I shall often look at you: I give you that
warning Beforehand, take it not ill my Masters,
I shall laugh at you; and truly when I am least offended
with you; my humour it is, but be not you abashed.
Sir we have played before a Lord ere now,
Though we be Country Actors
A lord, ha ha,
You will find it a harder thing to please a mayor
We have a play wherein we use a horse
Fellows you use no horse play in my house,
My rooms are rubbed, keep it for hackney men
We will not offer it to your worship: sir
Give me a play without a beast I Charge you
That is hard, without a Cuckold or a drunkard
O those Beasts are often the best men in the parish and must not be kept
out But which is your merriest play now, that would I hearken after.
Why your worship: shall hear the names all
over and take your Choice
And that is plain dealing trust me Come begin sir
The whirligig, the whible, Carwidghin
Hey day what names are these
New names of Late:
The wildgoose Chase
I understand thee now
Gull upon gull
Why this is somewhat plain yet
Woodcock of our side
Get you farther off then
The Cheater and the Clown
Is that Come up again
That was a play when I was prentice first
Aye but the Cheater has learned more tricks since sir
And gulls the Clown with new additions
Then is Clown a Coxcomb; which is he
I am the Clown sir
Fie, fie, your Company must fall upon him and beat him,
he is too fair to make the people laugh
Not as he may be dressed sir
Faith dress him how you will, I will give him that gift, he will
never look half scurvily enough: O the Clowns that I have
seen in my time, the very peeping out of them would have
made a young heir laugh if his father had lain a-dying;
A man undone in Law the day before; the saddest Case that Can
be; might for his two pence have burst himself with
laughing and ended all his miseries: here was a merry world
my Masters, some talk of things of state, of puling
Stuff, there is nothing in a play to a Clowns part, if he
have the grace to hit on it, that is the thing indeed:
The King shows well But he sets off the King
But not the King of Kent I mean not so
The King I mean, is one I do not know,
Your worship: speaks with safety like a rich man
and for your finding fault our hope is greater
Neither with him the Clown, or me the Cheater.
Away then shift Clown to thy motley Crupper
We will see them first, the King shall after supper.
I Commend your worship's: wisdom in that Master Mayor
Nay it is a point of Justice if it be well examined not to
offer the King worse than I will see myself; for a play may
be dangerous, I have known a great man poisoned in a play
What have you Master Mayor
But to what purpose many times I know not
Methinks they should destroy one another so
No no, he that is poisoned, is always made privy to it
That is one good order they have amongst them;
What joyful throat is that Aminadab
What is the meaning of this Cry
The Rebel is taken
Oliuer the puritan
Oliuer puritan and fustian weaver altogether
Fates I thank you for this victorious day
Bonfires of pees straw burn, let the bells ring
There is two amending sir you know they Cannot
Alas the tenor is Broken, ring forth the treble
I am ouer-cloyed with Joy, welcome thou Rebel
I scorn thy welcome
Art thou yet so stout
Wilt thou not stoop for grace, then get thee out.
I was not Born to stoop but to my loom
That Seized upon my stooping days are done,
In plain terms if thou hast anything to say to me send me away
quickly, this is no bidding place, I understand there is players
in the house, dispatch me I charge thee in the name of all the
Nay now proud Rebel, I will make thee staye
and to thy greater Torment see thee Play
O Devil I Conjure thee by Ansterdam
our word is past
Justice may wink awhile But see at Last
The play begins; hold stop him, stop him
O O that profane Trumpet
Set him down there I charge you officers
I will hide mine ears, and stop mine eyes.
Down with his golls I Charge you
O tyranny, revenge it tribulation
For rebels there are many Deaths; but sure the only way
To execute a Puritan is seeing of a Play,
O I shall swoon
But if thou dost, to fright thee
A players Boy shall Bring thee Aqua-vita
O I will not sound at all for it, though I die
Peace here is a rascal, list and edify
I say still he is an ass, that Cannot live by his wits
What a bold rascal is this; he Calls us all asses at first
dash; sure none of us lives by our wits neighbours, unless it
Be Oliuer the Puritan
I scorn as much to live by my wits, as the proudest of you all
Why you are an ass for Company Oliuer and so hold your
Fellows in arms welcome, the news, the news
Fellows in arms quotha, he may well Call them fellows
in arms, for they are all out of the elbows
Be lively my heart be lively, the Booty is in hand: he is
but a fool of a yeoman's eldest son, he Comes balanced on
both sides, Bully he is going to pay rent with the one pocket,
and buy household stuff with the other
And if this be his Last day my Chuck, he shall forfeit his
lease quoth the one pocket, and eat his meat in the old wooden
platters quoth the other
Faith then he is not so wise as he ought to be, if he let such
taterdemalians get the upper hand on him
He Comes he Comes
Aye but do you mark how he Comes; small to our Comfort,
with both his hands in his pockets, how is it possible
to pick a Lock when the key is on the inside of the door
Aye here is the part now neighbours that Carries away the
play, if the Clown miscarry, farewell my hopes
forever, the play is spoiled
They say there is a foolish thing Called Cheaters abroad,
that will gull any yeoman's son of his purse, and
laugh in his face like an Irishman, I would fain
meet with one of those Cheaters; I am in as good
state to be gulled now as ever I was in my Life, for I
have two purses at this time about me, and I would
fain be acquainted with that rascal that would but take one of
them now.
Faith thou mayst be acquainted with two or three, that will do
their good wills I warrant you
That way is too plain, too easy I am afraid
Come Come sir your familiar Cheats takes best
They show like natural things and least suspected
Give me a round shilling quickly
It will but fetch one of his hands neither, if it take
Thou art too Covetous, let us have one at first prithee
There is time enough to fetch out the other after
Thou Liest it is Lawful money, Currant money
Aye: so is Copper in some Countries sir
Here is a fray towards, But I will hold my hands
Let who will part them
Copper I defy thee
And now I shall disprove thee: look you sir,
Here Comes an honest yeoman's son of the Country
A man of Judgment
Pray be Covered sir
I have eggs in my Cap and Cannot put it off.
Will you be tried by him
I am Content sir
They look rather as if they would be tried next sessions
Pray give your Judgment of this piece of Coin sir
Nay if it be Coin you strive about let us see it,
I love to handle money
Look on it well sir
Let him do his worst sir
You had need to wear Cut Clothes, gent,
You are both so choleric.
Nay rub it and spare it not sir
Now by this silver Gentlemen it is good money
Would you had a hundred of them
We hope well sir,
The other pocket now and we are made men.
O neighbours I begin to be sick to see
This fool so Cozened, I would make the Case
mine own
Still would I fain meet with this thing Called Cheaters
A whoreson Coxcomb thy have met with thee,
I Can endure him no Longer with patience
O my rent my whole years rent
A murrain on you
This makes us Land Lords stay so long
without our money
The Cheaters have been here
A scurvy hobby horse that Could not leave his money with
me having such a Charge about him, a pox on thee for
an ass, thou play a Clown! I will Commit
thee for offering of it, officer away with him
What means your Worship? why you will spoil the Play, Sir.
Before the King of Kent shall be thus served,
I will play the Clown myself, away with him.
With me if it please your worship: it was my part
But it was as foolish a part as ever thou playedest in thy
Life, and I will make thee smoke for it, I will teach thee to
understand to play a Clown, thou shalt know every
man is not born to it: look thee, away with him
quickly he will have the other pocket, I heard him say it
with mine own ears,
see he Comes in another
disguise to Cheat thee again.
Pish whether goes he now, he spoils all my part
Come on sir let us see what your knaveship Can do at me
now, you must think now rascal you have no fool
in hand:

stage.l: discovering his doublet with a satten forepart

sp.l: the fool I have Committed for playing
the part so like an ass,
What is here to do
Fie good sir Come away:
Will your worship: base yourself to play a Clown
Away Brother it is not good to scorn anything: a man
does not know what he may Come to;
knows his ending but not his beginning, proceed varlet, do
thy worst, I defy thee:
I beseech your worship let us have
our own Clown, I know not
how to go forward else
Knave play out thy part with me, or I will lay thee by the heels all the
days of thy life else: why how now my Masters who is that laughed now;
Cannot a man of worship: play the Clown a little for his pleasure
but he must be laughed at; do you know who I am: is the Kings
deputy of no better accompt amongst you: was I Chosen to
be laughed at, where is my Clark
Here if it please your worship
Take a note of all those that laugh at me, that when I have done
I may Commit them, let me see who dares do it now: and now
to you once again sir Cheater; look you here is my purse
string I defy you:
Good sir tempt me not, my part is so written, that I should
cheat your worship: if you were my father.
I should have much joy to have such a rascal to my son
Therefore I beseech your worship: pardon me, the part has more knavery
than when your worship: saw it at first, I assure you you will be deceived
in it sir, the new addition will take any man's purse in Kent or
Christendom.
If thou Canst take mine now, I will give it thee freely
and do thy worst, I charge you as thou wilt answer it
I shall offend your worship:
Knave do it quickly
Say you so then, there is for you and here is for me then
O bless me neighbours I am in a fog
A Cheaters fog I Can see nobody
Run follow him officers
Away let him go, for he will have all your purses if he come back;
a pox of your new additions, they spoil all the plays that
ever they Come in, the old way had no such roguery in it, I
remember; Call you this a merry Comedy, when
as a man's eyes are put out, Brother Honnisuckle.
What says your sweet worship:
I make you my deputy to rule the Town, till I Can see again
which I hope will be within nine days at furthest: nothing
grieves me but that I hear Oliuer the rebel laugh at me;
a pox of your puritan face, this will make you in
love with plays ever hereafter, we shall not keep you
from them now
In Sincerity I was never
better edified at an
Neighbours what Colour is the rascals dust he threw in my face
It is meal if it please your worship.
Meal I am glad of it, I will hang the miller for selling
of it
Nay ten to one the Cheater never bought it,
He stole it Certainly
Why then I will hang the Cheater for stealing of it, and the
miller for being out of the way when he did it
Aye but your worship: was in the fault yourself,
You bad him do his worst
His worst that is true,
But he had done his best, the rascal,
For I know not how a villain could put out a man's eyes
better, and leave them in his head, than he has done
Where is my Masters worship:
How now Aminadab, I hear thee though I see thee not
You are sure Cozened sir, they are all Cheaters professed
They have stolen three spoons too and the Clown took his heels
with all Celerity: they only take the name of Country
Comedians to abuse simple people, with a printed play or two
They bought at Canterbury last week for six pence,
and which is worst they speak but what they list of it
and fribble out the rest
Here is no abuse to the Commonwealth
If a man Could see to look into it
But mark the Cunning of thee Cheating slaves
First they make Justice blind, then play the knaves
'Ods precious Brother the King of Kent is new lighted
The King of Kent where is he where is he
O that I should live to this day, and yet not live to see
To bid him welcome
Now where is symonides our friendly host
As blind as one that had been foxed a seven-night
Why how now man
Faith practising a Clowns part for your grace
I have practised both mine eyes out
What need you practise that
A man is never too old to learn: your grace will say so
when you hear all the villainy, the truth it is my Lord I
meant to have been merry, and now it is my Luck to
weep water and Oatmeal But I shall see again at supper
time I make no doubt of it
This is strange to me sirs
Arm arm my Lord
What is that
With swiftest speed,
If ever you will behold the Queen your daughter
Alive again
Roxena
They are Besieged
Aurelius Ambrose and his brother Vther
With numbers infinite in Britain forces
Beset their Castle, and they Cannot scape
without your speedy succour
For her safety
I will forget food and rest -- away
I hope
Your grace will hear the Jest afore you go
The Jest, torment me not, set forward
I will follow you
To wales with a dog and a bell but I will tell it you
Unreasonable folly
It is sign of war when great ones disagree
Look to the Rebel well till I Can see
and when my sight is recovered,
I will have his eyes putt out for a fortnight
Hang thee: mine eyes, a deadly sin or two
Shall pluck them out first, that is my resolution

stage.l: Enter Aurelius and Vther with Souldiers

sp.l: My Lord the Castle is so fortified
So fortified -- let wild fire ruin it
That his destruction may appear to him
In the figure of heavens wrath at the Last day;
That murderer of our Brother, hast away
I will send my heart no peace till it be Consumed,
There he appears again: behold my Lord
O that the zealous fire on my souls alter
To the high birth of virtue Consecrated,
Would fit me with a lightning now to blast him,
Even as I look upon him.
Good my Lord
Your anger is too noble and too precious
To waste itself on guilt so foul as his,
Let ruin work her will.
Begirt all round
All all my Lord: it is folly to make doubt of it;
You question things that horror long ago
Resolved us on.
Give me leave Hersus though
Do what you will sir question them again
I will tell them over to you.
Not so sir:
I will not have them told again
It rests then
That is an ill word putt in when thy heart knows
There is no rest at all, But torment making.
True, my heart finds it that sits weeping blood now
For poor Roxenas safety, you will Confess my Lord
My love to you has brought me to this danger;
I could have lived like hengist King of Kent,
and London yorke Lincolne and winchester
Under the power of my Command, the portion
Of my most just desert, it fell to it: enjoyed now
By pettier deservers;
Say you so sir
And you will Confess since you begin Confession
(A thing I should have died before I would thought of.)
I am out of your loves debt, in the sam Condition,
You have marred the fashion of your affection utterly
In your own
wicked Council; there you paid me,
You Could not but in Conscience love me afterwards,
You were bound to Do it, as men in honesty
That vitiate virgins to give dowries to them,
My faith was pure before to faithful woman
My Lord my Council
It is the map now spread
That shows me all my miseries, and discovers
Strange new found ruin to me, all these objects
That in a dangerous ring Circle my safety,
Are yours, and of your fashioning
Death mine:
Extremity breeds the wildness of a desert
Into your soul; and since, you have lost your thankfulness
Which is the noblest part in King or subject;
My Council do it,
Why I will be judged by those
That knit death in their Brows, and think me now
Not worthy the acceptance of a flattery;
Most of those faces smiled, when I smiled once
My Lords
Reply not Brother
Seeds of scorn
I mind you not; I speak to those alone
Whose force makes yours a power, which else were none:
Show me the main food of your hate, my Lords
Which Cannot be the murder of Constantius
That Crawls in your revenges, for your Love
Was violent Long since that
And had been still
If from that pagan woman, thou hadst slept free
But when thou fleddest from heaven we fled from thee
Was this your Council now
Mine, it was the Council
Of your own
Lust and blood; your appetite knows it
May thunder strike me from these walls my Lords
and leave me many leagues off from your eyes,
If this be not the man whose stygian soul
Breathed forth that Council to me, and sole plotter
Of all these false injurious disgraces
That have abused the virtuous patience
Of our religious queen
A devil in madness
Upon whose life I swear there sticks no stain
But what is most wrongful: and where now she thinks
A rape dwells in her honour,
only I
Her ravisher was, and his the policy
Inhumane practise
Now you know the truth
Will his death serve your fury
Mine my death
Will it do it
What if it would
Say will it do it
Say they should say it would
Why then it must
It must
It shall: speak but the words my Lord,
He shall be yielded up.
I yielded up,
My Lords believe him not, he Cannot do it,
Cannot
It is but a false and base insinuation
For his own Life,
and like his late submission
O sting to honour, alive or dead thou goest
For that words rudeness only
See sin needs
No more destruction than it breeds
In its own Bosom
Such another brings him
What, has thy wild rage stamped a wound upon me,
I will send one to thy soul shall never heal for it
How to my soul
It shall be thy Master torment
Both for the pain and the everlastingness
Ha ha
Dost laugh, take leave of it, all eternity
Shall never see thee do so much again
Know thou art a Cuckold
What
You Change too soon sir
Roxena whom thou hast raised to
She was my whore in Germany
Burst me open,
You violence of whirlwinds
Hear me out first
For her embrace which yet my flesh sits warm in
I was thy friend and follower
Deafen me
Thou most imperious noise that starts the world
and to serve both our Lusts, I practised with thee
Against thy virtuous Queen
Bane to all Comforts
Whose faithful sweetness, too precious for thy blood,
I made thee Change for loves hypocrisy
Insufferable
only to make my way
to pleasure fearless
Free and fluent
Hells trump is in that throat
It shall sound shriller
I will damn it up with Death first
I am at thy heart I hope
Hold out Breath
And I shall find thee quickly
O for succour
Who is near me, help me, save me, the flame follows me,
It is the figure of poor Vortiner the Prince
Whose life I took by poison
I will tug out
Thy soul here
Do monster
Vortiger
Monster
My Lord
Hersus Hersus
Murderer
My Lord
Toad Pagan
Viper Christian
Here me, help me,
My love my Lord, I am scorched, what all in Blood
O happy men, that ebb shows your near falling,
Have you Chose that way yourselves rather to die
by your own swords,
than feel fires keener Torment
and will not kill me, that most needs that pity,
Captain, my Lord, send me some speedier death
And one less painful, I have a woman's sufferings,
O think upon it, go not away so easily
And leave the harder Conflict to my weakness:
Most wretched; I am not worth so much destruction
As would destroy me quickly, and turn Back
I Cannot, O it is here, my Lord, it is here
Hersus look up if not to succour me
To see me yet Consumed, O what is Love
When Life is not regarded
What strength is left,
I will fix upon thy throat
I have some force yet
No way to scape; is this the end of glory
Doubly beset with enemies wrath and fire;
See, for an arm of Lust, I am now embraced
With one that will destroy me, where I read
The horror of dishonest actions, guile
and dissemblance: it comes nearer now, rivers
And fountains fall: tears were now a blessing
It sucks away my breath, I Cannot give
A Curs to sin, and hear it out whilst I live:
O help help help
Burn burn, now I Can tend thee,
Take time with her in torments, Call her Life
Afar off to thee, dry up her strumpet blood
and hardly parch the skin, let one heat strangle her
Another fetch her to her sense again,
and the worst pain be only her reviving
Follow her eternally:
give her not over
But in a bitter shape: I shall be Cold
Before thy rage reach me: O mystical harlot
Thou hast thy full due, whom Lust Crowned queen before
Flames Crown her now, for a triumphant whore.
and that end Crowns them all
our peace is full now
In yond usurpers fall; nor have I known
A judgment meet more fearefully:
Here take this Ring, deliver the good Queen
And those grave pledges of her injured honour,
Her worthy father and her noble uncle,
Too long, too much abused; whose Clear-eyed fames
I reverence with respect to holiness due,
A spotless name being sanctity now in few;
How now my Lords the meaning of these sounds,
The Consumer has been here, she is gone she is Lost,
In glowing Cinders now lies all my joys,
The headlong fortune of my rash Captivity
Strikes not so fierce a wound into my hopes
As thy dear Loss
Her father and her Uncle
They are indeed my Lord
Part of my wishes
What fortunate power has prevented me
And ere my Love Came, brought them victory.
My wonder sticks in Hengist king of Kent,
My Lord to make that plain which now I see
Fixed in astonishment, the only name
Of your return and being, brought such gladness
To this distracted kingdom, that to express
A thankfulness to heaven, it grew great
In Charitable actions, from which goodness
We tasted liberty, that lay engaged
Upon the innocence of woman's honour,
A kindness that even threatened to undo us,
and having newly But enjoyed the benefit
And fruits of our enlargement, it was our happiness,
To intercept this monster of Ambition,
Bred in these times of usurpation,
The rankness of whose insolence and treason
Grew to such height it was armed to bid you battle,
Whom as our fames redemption, on our knees
We present Captived.
Had it needed reason
You rightly Came provided, what is he
My Lord that treacherous Hengist King of Kent
I understand not your desert till now my Lords;
Is this that Germane Saxon, whose least thirst
Could not be satisfied under a province
Had but my fate directed this bold arm
To thy Life, the whole Kingdom had been mine
That was my hopes great aim, I have a thirst
Could never have been full quenched, under all;
The whale land must, or nothing
A strange drought
and what a little ground shall death now teach you
To be content withal.
Why let it then
For none else Can, you have named the only way;
When I am Content, it must be when I am clay.
My Lords the best requital yet we give you
Is a fair inward joy, Speak to your fames
Glories unblemished, for the Queen your Daughter
Lives firm in honour, neither by Consent
Or act of violence stained, as her grief judges;
It was her own Lord
abused her honest fear
Whose ends shamed him, only
to make her Clear
Had your grace given a Kingdom for a gift
It had not been so welcome
Here she Comes
Whose virtues I must reverence
O my Lord
I kneel a wretched woman,
Arise with me
Great in true joy and honour
This sight splits me
It Brings Roxenas ruin to my memory.
My Lord it is too great a joy for Life
It is truth, and that I know you ever joyed in,
His end Confessed it
Are you returned souls Comforts
Nay to approve thy pureness to posterity
The fruitful hopes of a fair peaceful Kingdom
Here will I plant
Too worthless are my merits
There speaks thy modesty, and to the firmness
Of Truths plantation in this Land forever,
Which always groans under some Curse without it,
As I begin my rule with the destruction
Of this ambitious Pagan, so shall all
With his adulterate faith distained, and soiled,
Either turn Christians, die, or live exiled.
A Blessing on those Virtues:
For story of Truth Compact
I chose these times, these men to act,
As Careful now to make you glad
As this were the first day they played --
And though some that give none their due
Please to mistake them; do not you
Whose Censures have been ever kind;
We hope it is good, But if we find
Your grace and love, by pleased signs understood
We cease to hope for them we know it is good.
